citations.narrative:
At the farm exhibit, the public is allowed to walk directly up to the primary enclosures that contain pigs and sheep with no
attendants or public barriers present. The primary enclosures’ fences and gates are approximately 4 feet high with
spacing between the wire mesh that allow hands or arms to reach through and touch the animals. Unattended public
contact does not ensure safe public interaction with the animals and may lead to injury of the public and/or the animals.
The licensee must ensure that during periods of public exhibition, animals are handled with sufficient distance and/or
barriers between the animals and the general viewing public to help assure the safety of both the animals and the public.

Per a facility representative, on June 12, 2024, a juvenile armadillo named "Torpedo" escaped his primary outdoor
enclosure. On June 10, 2024, he was placed in a newly repaired enclosure and escaped two days later. A newly repaired
section of the enclosure was then noted by staff to have a small gap in it that allowed the escape. Attempts to locate the
missing armadillo were unsuccessful. Failure to contain the animals can result in inability to access food or water, and
possibly result in injury and/or death. The enclosure must be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to
protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals.
Corrected prior to inspection.

The perimeter fences associated with the following outdoor primary enclosures are not adequate as follows:
• One corner of the perimeter fence for the cougars is attached to the primary enclosure, using it as part of the perimeter
fence, instead of having a secondary containment fence a minimum of 3 feet away.
• One portion of the perimeter fence for the foxes, by the access gate, is approximately 69 inches tall instead of the
required 72 inches (6 feet).
• At the wolves' primary enclosure, thick vegetation overgrowth is climbing and leaning over large sections of the
perimeter fence, facing the rear of the wolves' primary enclosure, creating a ladder that may allow unwanted animals to
easily enter the facility. Also, at the left side of the wolves' enclosure, the perimeter fence that attaches to the viewing
building is less than 3 feet from the primary enclosure. The spacing varies from approximately only 12 inches to up to 35
inches away from the primary enclosure for a distance of about 20 feet. Further, in this same area of the perimeter fence,
there is also a significant gap of approximately 6-8 inches below it for a length of about 6 feet which doesn't adequately
prevent other animals from passing through it.
The lack of an adequate perimeter fence presents a safety risk to the animals within the facility in that there isn’t an
adequate secondary containment system to hold animals that may escape their primary enclosures or a sufficient barrier
to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. The facility must ensure they maintain in good repair a continuous 8-foot-
high perimeter fencing for dangerous animals (cougars and wolves), and 6-foot-high fencing for non-dangerous animals
(foxes). Such fences must be at least 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure for animals housed outdoors.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by NOVEMBER 24, 2024, or the applicant will forfeit the
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License
Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
